docs/efr32main.md
1 EFR32 {#efr32_main}
2 ============
3 
4 While RAIL attempts to be chip agnostic there are certain hardware differences
5 that can't be overlooked. Where possible, missing features will be simulated in
6 software, but performance characteristics may vary. This section will cover what
7 differs for the EFR32 series of chips as well as any hardware specific
8 configurations or calibrations.
9 
10 ## Packet Buffer Restrictions
11 
12 Currently the RAIL library for the EFR32 allocates an internal buffer to store
13 the receive data contiguously. This buffer is set to 512 bytes at build time and
14 cannot be changed. This choice limits the maximum size of receive packets in
15 packet mode and determines the size of the receive FIFO in FIFO mode. Since each
16 receive packet has 6 bytes of overhead this means that you can only receive up
17 to one 506 byte packet without switching to FIFO mode. In FIFO mode you must
18 read out packet data as you approach this limit and store it off to construct
19 the full packet later. Note that this 6 byte overhead may increase or decrease
20 in future releases as we change functionality though we would not expect large
21 jumps in either direction.
22 
23 The transmit FIFO must be set at runtime with \ref RAIL_SetTxFifo(). Its size
24 must be a power of 2 from 64 to 4096 for hardware compatibility. Note that there
25 is no difference between packet and FIFO mode on the transmit side. A packet may
26 either be loaded all at once or in pieces using the \ref RAIL_WriteTxFifo()
27 function. You may also use the \ref RAIL_SetTxFifoThreshold() function and the
28 \ref RAIL_EVENT_TX_FIFO_ALMOST_EMPTY event to load data as there is space
29 available in the FIFO during transmission.
30 
31 ## Data Reception Sources
32 
33 When receiving data, you can configure hardware to provide data from three
34 different hardware sources.
35 
36 First, you can configure the hardware to provide a packet of information.
37 This configuration utilizes the built-in demodulator and frame controller.
38 Use \ref RAIL_RxDataSource_t::RX_PACKET_DATA to enable this receive source.
39 
40 Second, you can configure the hardware to provide data directly from the
41 demodulator. In this mode, the hardware demodulator is used, but the user is
42 responsible for implementing frame controller functionality. (i.e. Preamble
43 detection, sync word detection, CRC validation, etc. must be performed in
44 software by the application.) All data returned is represented as 8-bit
45 2's-compliment values. Use \ref RAIL_RxDataSource_t::RX_DEMOD_DATA to enable
46 this receive source.
47 
48 Third, you can configure the hardware to provide data directly from the I and
49 Q ADCs. In this mode, the user is responsible for implementing demodulator and
50 frame controller functionality. The receive signal hardware has a 19-bit
51 dynamic range, and the user can select whether to return the upper 16 bits of
52 the 19-bit value (\ref RAIL_RxDataSource_t::RX_IQDATA_FILTMSB) or the lower 16
53 bits (\ref RAIL_RxDataSource_t::RX_IQDATA_FILTLSB). All data returned is
54 represented as 16-bit 2s-compliment values. The I and Q values are put into the
55 buffer in an alternating fashion where the first 16-bit value is the first I
56 ADC value, and the second 16-bit value is the first Q ADC value, etc.
57 
58 ## Interrupt Vectors
59 
60 The RAIL library for EFR32 implements all of the interrupt vectors for radio
61 peripherals. This is required for the RAIL library to function correctly. RAIL
62 does not, however, set the priorities of these interrupt vectors. That must be
63 handled by your application using the CMSIS NVIC_SetPriority() API or direct
64 manipulation of the NVIC. Below is the full list of interrupts used by the
65 radio. You __must__ run them all at the same priority which is what all Silicon
66 Labs RAIL applications do by default. You are free to choose what that priority
67 is based on the requirements of your application (e.g. putting them below
68 FreeRTOS atomic for access to OS functions in RAIL callbacks). Keep in mind that
69 putting the radio interrupts at too low a priority can cause missed packets and
70 other radio performance issues. A restriction on EFR32xG12 and newer is that you
71 must not disable radio interrupts for longer than a quarter of the RAIL timebase
72 (2^32/4 microseconds or 18 minutes) to ensure proper timekeeping. Please see
73 \ref EFR32xG1x_Interrupts or follow the links below for more information.
74 
75 ~~~~~~~~~~{.c}
76 FRC_PRI_IRQHandler
77 FRC_IRQHandler
78 MODEM_IRQHandler
79 RAC_SEQ_IRQHandler
80 RAC_RSM_IRQHandler
81 BUFC_IRQHandler
82 AGC_IRQHandler
83 PROTIMER_IRQHandler
84 SYNTH_IRQHandler
85 RFSENSE_IRQHandler
86 ~~~~~~~~~~

88 # Chip Specific Initialization
89 
90 ## EFR32 Hardware Initialization
91 
92 The EFR32 comes with versions of EMLIB and EMDRV to create a basic HAL layer.
93 A lot of this initialization code is completely up to you, but there are a
94 couple of requirements when you're building a RAIL app. Specifically, the radio
95 will only work if you are running off a high precision crystal oscillator. Since
96 some APIs will assume this is running you should make sure to initialize and
97 switch to the crystal before calling any radio APIs.
98 
99 For the WSTK you can use the crystal configuration in the HAL config header file
100 for your specific kit. Example code for this is shown below. If you have a
101 custom hardware layout you may want to create your own HFXOInit structure to
102 account for things like your specific CTUNE value.
103 
104 ~~~~~~~~~~{.c}
105 #include "bsp.h" // Contains WSTK versions of the HFXO init structure
106 
107 void efrStartup(void)
108 {
109  CMU_HFXOInit_TypeDef hfxoInit = CMU_HFXOINIT_WSTK_DEFAULT;
110 
111  // Initialize the HFXO using the settings from the WSTK bspconfig.h
112  // Note: This configures things like the capacitive tuning CTUNE variable
113  // which can vary based on your hardware design.
114  CMU_HFXOInit(&hfxoInit);
115 
116  // Switch HFCLK to HFXO and disable HFRCO
117  CMU_ClockSelectSet(cmuClock_HF, cmuSelect_HFXO);
118  CMU_OscillatorEnable(cmuOsc_HFRCO, false, false);
119 }
120 ~~~~~~~~~~
121 
122 ## Radio Specific Initialization
123 
124 Currently there are two initialization functions for the radio that depend on
125 your board configuration and must be manually called at startup: \ref
126 RAIL_ConfigTxPower() and \ref RAIL_ConfigPti(). You __MUST__ initialize the
127 power amplifier (PA) in order to transmit. You may initialize the packet trace
128 interface (PTI) if you want to use this for debugging.
129 
130 
131 ### Power Amplifier (PA) Initialization
132 
133 There are three different PAs available for the EFR32xG1 family of chips:
134 the [High Power 2.4GHz PA](\ref RAIL_TX_POWER_MODE_2P4_HP), the
135 [Low Power 2.4GHz PA](\ref RAIL_TX_POWER_MODE_2P4_LP), and the
136 [Sub GHz PA](\ref RAIL_TX_POWER_MODE_SUBGIG). The
137 specific set of PAs you have available and the supported power levels for those
138 PAs are determined by your part number. Consult the data sheet for more details.
139 
140 Each PA supports a raw power level value of type \ref RAIL_TxPowerLevel_t where
141 a numerically smaller number causes less power to be output from the chip than a
142 higher number. Keep in mind that these values may be capped at the upper and
143 lower ends and do not necessarily map linearly to output power in dBm. To map
144 these values to and from dBm values the RAIL library uses the \ref
145 RAIL_ConvertRawToDbm() and \ref RAIL_ConvertDbmToRaw() APIs. By default, these
146 use whatever piecewise linear power curves were passed into
147 RAIL_InitTxPowerCurves() to do the conversion. On Silicon Labs boards these
148 curves are included with the board header files. For custom boards this must be
149 measured using test equipment to take into account the differences in the RF
150 path that may exist. In addition for even more custom use cases the conversion
151 functions can be strongly defined in the customer application and provide
152 whatever type of mapping is found to be most effective. Below is an example of
153 using the standard APIs to initialize all PAs on a dual band chip and switch to
154 the 2.4GHz high power PA.
155 
156 ~~~~~~~~~~{.c}
157 #include "rail.h"
158 #include "rail_chip_specific.h"
159 #include "plugin/pa-conversion/pa_conversion_efr32.h"
160 
161 RAIL_DECLARE_TX_POWER_VBAT_CURVES(piecewiseSegments, curvesSg, curves24Hp, curves24Lp);
162 
163 // Must be called with a valid RAIL_Handle_t returned by RAIL_Init()
164 void initPa(RAIL_Handle_t myRailHandle)
165 {
166  // Initialize the RAIL Tx power curves for all PAs on this chip
167  RAIL_TxPowerCurvesConfig_t txPowerCurvesConfig = {
168  curves24Hp,
169  curvesSg,
170  curves24Lp,
171  piecewiseSegments
172  };
173  if (RAIL_InitTxPowerCurves(&txPowerCurvesConfig) != RAIL_STATUS_NO_ERROR) {
174  // Could not initialize transmit power curves so something is configured
175  // wrong. Please fix and rebuild.
176  while(1);
177  }
178 
179  // Switch to the 2.4GHz HP PA powered off the 1.8V DCDC connection
180  RAIL_TxPowerConfig_t railTxPowerConfig = {
181  RAIL_TX_POWER_MODE_2P4_HP, // 2.4GHz HP Power Amplifier mode
182  1800, // 1.8V vPA voltage for DCDC connection
183  10 // Desired ramp time in us
184  };
185  if (RAIL_ConfigTxPower(myRailHandle, &railTxPowerConfig)
186  != RAIL_STATUS_NO_ERROR) {
187  // Error: The requested PA could not be selected. Fix your configuration
188  // and try again.
189  while(1);
190  }
191 
192  // Set the output power to the maximum supported by this chip
193  RAIL_SetTxPower(myRailHandle, 255);
194 }
195 ~~~~~~~~~~
196 
197 ### Packet Trace Interface (PTI) Initialization
198 
199 Packet trace on the EFR32 provides a mechanism for viewing transmitted and
200 received radio packets for network sniffing or debugging. It can also be
201 captured by a WSTK and sent to Simplicity Studio for viewing the data in its
202 Network Analyzer tool.
203 
204 If you want to use this functionality, you must configure what pins you want to
205 use for this output and, optionally how you want to format the data. Note that
206 the WSTK _requires_ the following output format:
207 
208  Mode: 8 bit UART mode
209  Baudrate: 1.6Mbps
210  Framing Signal: Enabled
211 
212 If you change anything here it is currently unsupported by the WSTK. In the
213 future we may include support for alternate output modes.
214 
215 To choose the pins you want you must look in the data sheet for your part and
216 select a valid route location for the FRC_DOUT and FRC_DFRAME signals. These map
217 to PTI.DATA and PTI.FRAME on the WSTK respectively. Once you've found pins that
218 work for your hardware you need to configure the RouteLocation, port, and pin
219 fields in the PTI initialization structure. When using the WSTK for example,
220 you should initialize things as follows.
221 
222 ~~~~~~~~~~{.c}
223 #include "rail.h"
224 #include "rail_chip_specific.h"
225 
226 void initPti(void)
227 {
228  RAIL_PtiConfig_t ptiConfig = {
229  RAIL_PTI_MODE_UART, // Only supported output mode for the WSTK
230  1600000, // Choose 1.6 Mbps for the WSTK
231  6, // WSTK uses location 6 for DOUT
232  gpioPortB, // FRC_DOUT#6 is PB12
233  12, // FRC_DOUT#6 is PB12
234  6, // UNUSED IN UART MODE
235  gpioPortB, // UNUSED IN UART MODE
236  11, // UNUSED IN UART MODE
237  6, // WSTK uses location 6 for DFRAME
238  gpioPortB, // FRC_DOUT#6 is PB13
239  13, // FRC_DOUT#6 is PB13
240  };
241 
242  // Initialize the Packet Trace Interface (PTI) for the EFR32
243  RAIL_ConfigPti(RAIL_EFR32_HANDLE, &ptiConfig);
244 
245  // Enable Packet Trace (PTI)
246  RAIL_EnablePti(RAIL_EFR32_HANDLE, true);
247 }
248 ~~~~~~~~~~
249 
250 ### Other Radio GPIO Functions
251 
252 There are various useful signals related to the radio that can be output on a
253 GPIO using the Peripheral Reflex System (PRS). The PRS is an advanced system
254 where you can route signals to channels and then output those channels to a
255 number of configurable locations. There's a lot more to it than that, so
256 consult the reference manual chapter on the PRS if you want to understand it
257 better.
258 
259 A list of some of the most interesting PRS signals related to the radio is shown
260 below along with how to enable them in the PRS. The definition for these signals
261 for a given chip can be found in the release at
262 `platform/Device/SiliconLabs/<chipFamily>/Include/<chipFamily>_prs_signals.h`
263 where `<chipFamily>` would be the beginning of the part number (EFR32MG12P for
264 example).
265 
266 | Signal | Summary |
267 |:--------------------|:----------------------|
268 | PRS_RAC_ACTIVE | Radio enabled |
269 | PRS_RAC_TX | Transmit mode enabled |
270 | PRS_RAC_RX | Receive mode enabled |
271 | PRS_RAC_LNAEN | LNA enabled for Rx |
272 | PRS_RAC_PAEN | PA enabled for Tx |
273 | PRS_MODEM_FRAMEDET | Frame detected |
274 | PRS_MODEM_PREDET | Preamble detected |
275 | PRS_MODEM_TIMDET | Timing detected |
276 | PRS_MODEM_FRAMESENT | Frame sent |
277 | PRS_MODEM_SYNCSENT | Syncword sent |
278 | PRS_MODEM_PRESENT | Preamble sent |
279 
280 The example below shows you how to configure a PRS channel to output RAC_RX on
281 a GPIO. For this example we assume you're using the WSTK with the BRD4153A radio
282 board. If so, the code below will put RACRX on PRS Channel 0 and output PRS
283 Channel 0 on pin PC10 which is wired to WSTK_P12 and EXP_HEADER15 on the WSTK.
284 
285 ~~~~~~~~~{.c}
286 #include "em_cmu.h"
287 #include "em_prs.h"
288 #include "em_gpio.h"
289 #include "em_device.h"
290 
291 void enableDebugGpios(void)
292 {
293  // Turn on the PRS and GPIO clocks so we can access their registers
294  CMU_ClockEnable(cmuClock_PRS, true);
295  CMU_ClockEnable(cmuClock_GPIO, true);
296 
297  // Configure PC10 as an output
298  GPIO_PinModeSet(gpioPortC, 10, gpioModePushPull, 0);
299 
300  // Configure PRS Channel 0 to output RACRX
301  PRS_SourceSignalSet(0,
302  ((PRS_RAC_RX & _PRS_CH_CTRL_SOURCESEL_MASK)
303  >> _PRS_CH_CTRL_SOURCESEL_SHIFT),
304  ((PRS_RAC_RX & _PRS_CH_CTRL_SIGSEL_MASK)
305  >> _PRS_CH_CTRL_SIGSEL_SHIFT),
306  prsEdgeOff);
307 
308  // Configure PRS Channel 0 to use output location 12 (PC10 - see datasheet)
309  PRS->ROUTELOC0 &= ~_PRS_ROUTELOC0_CH0LOC_MASK;
310  PRS->ROUTELOC0 |= PRS_ROUTELOC0_CH0LOC_LOC12;
311 
312  // Enable PRS Channel 0
313  PRS->ROUTEPEN |= PRS_ROUTEPEN_CH0PEN;
314 }
315 ~~~~~~~~~

317 ## Required Dependencies
318 
319 Most of the RAIL library is self contained, however, there are some dependencies
320 on external functions. Specifically, we rely on functions from the C standard
321 library, EMLIB, and CMSIS. Below is a complete list of these dependencies. If
322 you want to change the implementation of any of these functions while
323 maintaining the functionality that's fine, just know that they could impact RAIL
324 operation.
325 
326 | Group | Functions |
327 |-------|-----------|
328 | CMSIS | `SystemHFXOClockGet()`<br>`SystemHFClockGet()`<br>`SystemLFRCOClockGet()`<br>`SystemLFXOClockGet()`<br>`SystemULFRCOClockGet()`|
329 | EMLIB (em_cmu) | `CMU_ClockEnable`<br>`CMU_ClockFreqGet`<br>`CMU_ClockPrescGet`<br>`CMU_ClockPrescSet`<br>`CMU_ClockSelectGet`<br>`CMU_ClockSelectSet`<br>`CMU_OscillatorEnable`<br> |
330 | EMLIB (em_gpio) | `GPIO_PinModeSet()` |
331 | EMLIB (em_system) | `SYSTEM_ChipRevisionGet()` |
332 | EMLIB (em_core) | `CORE_EnterCritical()`<br>`CORE_ExitCritical()`<br>`CORE_EnterAtomic()`<br>`CORE_ExitAtomic()` |
333 | EMLIB (em_emu) | `EMU_DCDCLnRcoBandSet()` |
334 | stdlib | `memcpy()`<br>`memset()` |

336 ## Peripherals Consumed by RAIL
337 
338 Currently, RAIL consumes only peripherals that are a part of the radio.
339 
340 ### Future Peripheral Considerations
341 
342 In the future, RAIL might use a few of the customer facing peripherals for
343 enhanced functionality. In preparation, below is a list of potential
344 peripherals that could be shared in future RAIL releases.
345 
346 * PRS Channels
347 * RTCC Timer
348 
349 ## Entropy Generation
350 
351 The EFR32 supports true entropy collection using the radio. It is able to
352 collect 1 bit per radio clock cycle while in receive mode. This means that we
353 must enable the receiver when collecting entropy and if you attempt to transmit
354 or otherwise delay entry into receive it will take us a longer time to collect
355 the data. You can still receive packets while collecting entropy and this does
356 mean that requesting random numbers longer than the length of your preamble and
357 sync word may trigger a packet reception. This may be fixed in a future revision
358 but for now this is done to ensure proper packet reception during random data
359 collection.
360 
361 Due to the nature of random data collection we will always wait for the full
362 amount requested so we should return either the number of bytes requested or
363 zero. Zero is returned if the radio is uninitialized and cannot be enabled for
364 collection.
365 
366 ## RAIL Timebase
367 
368 The EFR32 uses a dedicated radio timer to create the RAIL timebase and perform
369 scheduled transmit and receive operations. This timer ticks at roughly every 2us
370 on the EFR32xG1 platform and 0.5us on the EFR32xG12 and newer. The exact tick
371 value depends on the high frequency crystal in use so there may be some small
372 rounding error. All internal APIs account for this error so over long periods of
373 time it is generally unnoticeable. Note that RAIL uses the hardware tick rate to
374 create the 1us time base that is exposed to the user. This is all that should
375 matter for most users and the information here is only to allow you to better
376 understand the underlying implementation.
377 
378 ## Radio Calibration
379 
380 The EFR32 supports two radio calibration options: image rejection (IR)
381 calibration and VCO temperature calibration. You may choose to enable one or
382 both of these based upon your specific situation. We always recommend using
383 both for optimal performance of the radio.
384 
385 * Image Rejection Calibration (IRCAL)
386  * This calibration should be run once every time your PHY config changes. It
387  is based on the modulation scheme, frequency band, and other radio settings.
388  RAIL will request this by calling \ref RAIL_Config_t::eventsCallback with the \ref
389  RAIL_EVENT_CAL_NEEDED bit set and the \ref RAIL_CAL_ONETIME_IRCAL bit set
390  in \ref RAIL_GetPendingCal().
391  * Using a proper value for this will improve sensitivity by several dBm, so
392  it's highly recommended.
393  * It can take on the order of 700 ms to complete this calibration.
394  You may want to save off a known good value for this calibration and load
395  it each time you switch PHYs to save time.
396  * This calibration should be initialized before calling
397  \ref RAIL_ConfigChannels() to ensure that it is properly configured by the
398  time the first channel is setup. This initialization involves enabling the
399  algorithm and passing in parameters to configure the algorithm for the
400  specific PHY generated by the EFR32 Radio Configurator.
401  * You cannot use the radio while this calibration is being performed or you
402  may generate an incorrect calibration. Application code should ensure that
403  the radio remains in the idle state during this calibration.
404  * This calibration is only meaningful for Zigbee, BLE, and sub GHz radio
405  configurations. For all others you should still enable the calibration but
406  the algorithm will apply a safe, default calibration value.
407 * VCO Temperature Calibration (VCO_TEMPCAL)
408  * If you sit in receive for a very long time and experience temperature swings
409  it's possible for the radio to drift off frequency. When this situation is
410  detected RAIL will request this calibration via \ref RAIL_Config_t::eventsCallback with
411  the \ref RAIL_EVENT_CAL_NEEDED bit set and the \ref RAIL_CAL_TEMP_VCO bit
412  set in RAIL_CalPendingGet().
413  * This calibration is automatically run every time we enter receive. So if you
414  are frequently forcing a re-enter into receive mode you may not need to
415  enable this calibration.
416  * On EFR, the application will get this event when the absolute temperature
417  crosses 0C degrees as well as when the temperature delta from the last
418  calibration increases or decreases by 70C.
419  * We always recommend that you enable and handle this calibration since it
420  doesn't add much overhead and is much safer if you ever do end up in this
421  situation.
422 
423 ## State Transition Timing
424 
425 The EFR32 allows automatic transitions from receive to transmit, in order to
426 precisely time transmitted packets after packet reception. During this process,
427 some internal calculations are done which require the received packet's
428 duration, from sync word to end of CRC, to be less than 32 ms. If some received
429 packets in a given protocol have an on-air time greater than 32 ms, the
430 automatic transition from receive to transmit may not be used with that
431 protocol, as the timing of that transition will be incorrect.
